channel.title: Data Science on Infectious Perspectives
channel.description: Recent content in Data Science on Infectious Perspectives

item.title: Machine Learning Approaches for Predicting Remission Status: Lasso, Random Forest & Adaboost
item.description: What can you learn from this article? Using regularized methods (Lasso) for predictive variable selection Tuning hyperparameters for tree-based methods Applying weak learner for sequnectial Comparing prediction performances and predictor importance across learners Basic Methods Inmagine you possess a dataset comprising 30 biomarker varaibles. How would you use it to predict patient’s remission status, i.e. remission or active diseae? One common approach that may cross your mind is the logistic regression, as illustrated below:

item.title: Minimizing data linkage error in an ETL pipeline using R: an intersection of MIMIC III and ODK database
item.description: What can you learn from this article? Understand the concepts of data linkage, especially deterministic linakge. Address linkage error in the conjunction of MIMIC III (served in a postgreSQL database) and ODK database. Employ R to design the Extract, Transform, and Load (ETL) pipeline. Use Quarto document to generate a report in PDF format. Concepts of Data Linkage In a data scientist’s typical day, the merge/join function is an inevitable task.

item.title: Navigating Short-Term Accommodation Search in London
item.description: This year, London home rental prices hit record as demand outstriped supply, with the average tenant now being asked to pay a whopping Â£2,500 a month for a new let. Within this rental market, individuals seeking short-term accommodations encounter greater challenges. My roommates and I was looking for a house/flat for co-renting with a 6-month tenancy, and we put in a significant effort throughout the entire month of August by searching and making inquiries about over 170 properties before finally settling down.
